Structs/HomogenousTree.html.name: HomogenousTree
Structs/HomogenousTree.html.abstract: HomogenousTree is used as the default form of AbstractSyntaxTree. Each node in the tree captures its Token, the String it mtached, and any children.

Protocols/Token.html#/s:9OysterKit5Token.abstract: Create a rule that will consume as many of the characters in the supplied set as possible. No token will be issued.

Protocols/IntermediateRepresentation.htm.name: willEvaluate(rule:at:)
Protocols/IntermediateRepresentation.htm.abstract: Called when the parser is about to evaluate a rule. This is an oppertunity to prepare any appropriate data structures.

Protocols/IntermediateRepresentation.htm.name: didEvaluate(rule:matchResult:)

Protocols/IntermediateRepresentation.htm.name: didBuild()

Protocols/IntermediateRepresentation.htm.name: resetState()

Protocols/LexicalAnalyzer.html#/s:9Oyste.abstract: : Discards the current mark, rewinding the scanner to that position

Protocols/LexicalAnalyzer.html#/s:9Oyste.name: proceed()
Protocols/LexicalAnalyzer.html#/s:9Oyste.abstract: : Discards the current mark, but leaving the scanner at it’s current location

Protocols/LexicalAnalyzer.html#/s:9Oyste.abstract: Advances the scanner one character. If the end of the source String has already been reached a Error should be thrown.

Protocols/LexicalAnalyzer.html#/s:9Oyste.abstract: Should return the String from the source representing the supplied range.

Protocols/DecodeableAbstractSyntaxTree.h.abstract: The String the was matched for the node

Protocols/DecodeableAbstractSyntaxTree.h.name: key
Protocols/DecodeableAbstractSyntaxTree.h.abstract: Should be the CodingKey for this node. This is normally generated using the name of the Token.

Protocols/DecodeableAbstractSyntaxTree.h.name: contents
Protocols/DecodeableAbstractSyntaxTree.h.abstract: Should be the children of this node

Protocols/DecodeableAbstractSyntaxTree.h.name: subscript(_:)

Protocols/DecodeableAbstractSyntaxTree.h.name: subscript(key:)

Protocols/DecodeableAbstractSyntaxTree.h.name: DecodeableAbstractSyntaxTree
Protocols/DecodeableAbstractSyntaxTree.h.abstract: This protocol identifies as set of additional requirements for Nodes in order for them to be used for decoding. Some elements of the implementation are

Protocols/LexicalAnalyzer.html.name: LexicalAnalyzer
Protocols/LexicalAnalyzer.html.abstract: The job of an implementation of this protocol is two fold

Protocols/LexicalContext.html.name: LexicalContext
Protocols/LexicalContext.html.abstract: A lexical context summarises the of a String being scanned by a LexicalAnalyzer between two marks. It is generated when the LexicalAnalyzer is advanced

Protocols/AbstractSyntaxTree.html.name: AbstractSyntaxTree
Protocols/AbstractSyntaxTree.html.abstract: Abstract Syntax Trees are responsible to for taking an IntermediateRepresentation and building a data structure suitable for semantic analysis

Protocols/Node.html.name: Node
Protocols/Node.html.abstract: Nodes are the basic elements of IntermediateRepresentations. They record a Token, the range of the String‘s UnicodeScalarView the match occured in

Protocols/IntermediateRepresentation.htm.name: IntermediateRepresentation
Protocols/IntermediateRepresentation.htm.abstract: An IntermediateRepresentation is responsible for building this structure, typically some kind of Abstract Syntax Tree (AST).

Protocols/HumanConsumableError.html.name: HumanConsumableError
Protocols/HumanConsumableError.html.abstract: To be implemented by any error that is expected to be meaningful to a user looking at parsing results

Protocols/Language.html.name: Language
Protocols/Language.html.abstract: A language stores a set of grammar rules that can be used to parse Strings. Extensions provide additional methods (such as parsing) that operate on these rules.

Protocols/Token.html.name: Token
Protocols/Token.html.abstract: Tokens are generated when rules are matched (usually, sometime a rule just advances the scan-head). Tokens with a rawValue of -1 are considered transient, meaning that they should not be included in any construction of an AST. However, they may provide context to the AST.

Protocols/Rule.html.name: Rule
Protocols/Rule.html.abstract: The protocol that parsing and scanning rules must adhere to. There is no need to fully implement this protocol unless you are looking for bespoke LexicalAnalyzer or IntermediateRepresentation control. It is recommended to use ParserRule.custom in almost all cases.

Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.name: combinedRange
Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.abstract: Returns the combined range of all Nodes in the Collection essentially setting the lowerBound to the lowest of all range, and upperBound to the highest of all ranges.

Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.name: perpetual
Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.abstract: Returns a new Collection with any transient nodes filtered out

Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.name: merge(with:)
Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.abstract: Creates a new collection of RuleAnnotations where the merged annotations override those in

Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.name: stlrDescription
Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.abstract: A description in STLR format of the RuleAnnotations

Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.name: sequence(token:annotations:)
Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.abstract: Creates a new rule that requires that all rules in this array are found one after another.

Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.name: oneOf(token:annotations:)
Extensions/Collection.html#/s:s10Collect.abstract: Creates a new rule that requires one of all the rules in this array must be matched.

Extensions/Decodable.html#/s:s9Decodable.name: decode(_:using:)
Extensions/Decodable.html#/s:s9Decodable.abstract: Creates a new instance of the Decodeable using the supplied source and language.

Extensions/Decodable.html#/s:s9Decodable.name: decode(_:with:using:)
Extensions/Decodable.html#/s:s9Decodable.abstract: Creates a new instance of the Decodeable using the supplied source and language. You typically do not need to use this

Extensions/Decodable.html.name: Decodable
Extensions/Decodable.html.abstract: Makes it possible for any Decodable to be constructed using a source string and language. You can specify your own

Extensions/Array.html.name: Array
Extensions/Array.html.abstract: Extensions to an array where the elements are Rules

Extensions/Collection.html.name: Collection
Extensions/Collection.html.abstract: An extension to make it easy to operate on any collection of Nodes

Extensions/Int.html.name: Int
Extensions/Int.html.abstract: An extension to allow any Int to be used as a Token.

Enums/ScannerRule.html#/s:9OysterKit11Sc.abstract: Scanner rules cannot have annotations. All scanner rules can be modelled with

Enums/RuleAnnotation.html#/s:9OysterKit1.name: error

Enums/RuleAnnotation.html#/s:9OysterKit1.name: transient

Enums/RuleAnnotation.html#/s:9OysterKit1.name: custom

Enums/RuleAnnotation.html#/s:9OysterKit1.name: hashValue
Enums/RuleAnnotation.html#/s:9OysterKit1.abstract: The searchable hash value of the annotation
Compares two annotations for equality (not values, but keys)

Enums/RuleAnnotation.html#/s:9OysterKit1.name: description
Enums/RuleAnnotation.html#/s:9OysterKit1.abstract: A human readable description of the annotation

Enums/MatchResult.html#/s:9OysterKit11Ma.name: matchedString
Enums/MatchResult.html#/s:9OysterKit11Ma.abstract: The substring of the source that the match was against

Enums/ParserRule.html#/s:9OysterKit10Par.name: not

Enums/ParserRule.html#/s:9OysterKit10Par.name: custom
Enums/ParserRule.html#/s:9OysterKit10Par.abstract: Matches using the supplied CustomRuleClosure. This is the recommended way of implementing custom rules as it means you do not need

Enums/LanguageError.html#/s:9OysterKit13.name: scanningError
Enums/LanguageError.html#/s:9OysterKit13.abstract: An error in scanning (for example illegal scanning range), the index and message to be displayed. This is the lowest level of error

Enums/LanguageError.html#/s:9OysterKit13.name: semanticError

Enums/LanguageError.html#/s:9OysterKit13.name: range

Enums/LanguageError.html#/s:9OysterKit13.name: description

Determine if one error is exactly the same as another. The range and message must be == to each other

Enums/GrammarError.html#/s:9OysterKit12G.abstract: Recursive rule references itself without advancing the scanner

Enums/GrammarError.html#/s:9OysterKit12G.name: notImplemented

Enums/GrammarError.html#/s:9OysterKit12G.abstract: Whilst trying to match a token the rule failed (the text did not match). This should be expected during parsing.

Enums/GrammarError.html.name: GrammarError
Enums/GrammarError.html.abstract: An enumeration of the Errors that can occur during parsing.

Enums/LanguageError.html.name: LanguageError
Enums/LanguageError.html.abstract: Any error generated by the underlying parsing engine. These are generally replaced if they occur by any @error annotations.

Enums/ParserRule.html.name: ParserRule
Enums/ParserRule.html.abstract: A standard set of Rules for parsing, including a .custom case where a CustomRuleClosure can be supplied and you only need to provide

Enums/MatchResult.html.name: MatchResult
Enums/MatchResult.html.abstract: Match results are passed from Rules to IntermediateRepresentations and provide all information required to create an AST or even begin

Enums/RuleAnnotationValue.html.name: RuleAnnotationValue
Enums/RuleAnnotationValue.html.abstract: Represents the value for a rule annotation

Enums/RuleAnnotation.html.name: RuleAnnotation
Enums/RuleAnnotation.html.abstract: An annotation that can be associated with any rule influencing how matches are interpretted and providing additional data about the token. The following annotations represent reserved words, but otherwise you can define any annotations you want.

Enums/ScannerRule.html.name: ScannerRule
Enums/ScannerRule.html.abstract: A set of low level rules that operate only on terminals. These are much faster than ParserRules

Classes/Lexer.html.name: Lexer

Classes/AbstractSyntaxTreeConstructor.ht.name: AbstractSyntaxTreeConstructor
Classes/AbstractSyntaxTreeConstructor.ht.abstract: AbstractSyntaxTreeConstructor is an IntermediateRepresentation responsible for briding between the parsing results and an AbstractSyntaxTree.

Classes/TokenStream.html.name: TokenStream
Classes/TokenStream.html.abstract: A TokenStream provides lazy iterators that minimize memory consumption and overhead allowing you to iterate through the tokens created by the

Classes/NodeStackEntry.html.name: NodeStackEntry
Classes/NodeStackEntry.html.abstract: NodeStackEntry‘s are used to capture parsing context (for example child-nodes and errors) ASTs are constructed.

Classes/NodeStack.html.name: NodeStack
Classes/NodeStack.html.abstract: A NodeStack can be used to manage AST construction state, as new rule evaluations begin new contexts can be pushed onto the node stack and then popped and discarded on failure, or popped and acted on for success.

Classes/Parser.html.name: Parser
Classes/Parser.html.abstract: A default implementation of a Language. AST construction is automatically provided by standard extensions to Language

Classes/StateCache.html.name: StateCache
Classes/StateCache.html.abstract: A generic cache that can be used in your own IntermediateRepresentation

Classes/RecursiveRule.html.name: RecursiveRule
Classes/RecursiveRule.html.abstract: When a rule definition calls itself whilst evaluating itself (left hand recursion) you cannot create the rule directly as it will become caught in an infinite look (creating instances of itself, which create instances of itself etc until the stack is empty). To avoid this a rule can use this wrapper to manage lazy initialization of itself. The recursive rule enables a reference to be added on the RHS, but the actual rule will not be initiialized until later, and this wrapper will then call that lazily initalized rule.

Global Variables.html.abstract: The following global variables are available globally.
